title: Mysterious Red Dots in Space Photos Solved
summary: The James Webb Space Telescope took pictures of space and found strange red dots. Scientists from the University of Copenhagen studied them for two years. They discovered these red dots are young black holes. Black holes are very strong objects that pull in gas and dust. The black holes are hidden inside thick clouds of gas. When they eat the gas, it gets very hot and glows red. This makes the red dots we see. The black holes are not as big as people thought. They are about 10 million times heavier than the Sun. Scientists call them 'messy eaters' because they blow out most of the gas instead of swallowing it. This helps us learn how black holes grow in the early universe.

keywords.explanation: a big telescope in space that takes pictures of stars and galaxies
small red points of light seen in space photos
strong objects in space that pull in gas and dust
thick clouds of gas that hide black holes
a nickname for black holes because they blow out gas when eating

questions.question: What telescope found the red dots?
Where are the black holes hidden?
Why do the red dots glow red?
options: Because the gas gets hot when eaten
Because they are made of fire
questions.correct_answer: Because the gas gets hot when eaten

questions.question: How heavy are the black holes compared to the Sun?
What nickname do scientists give black holes in this story?

background_read: The James Webb Space Telescope is a powerful telescope launched in 2021 to look at distant space. Black holes are mysterious objects with strong gravity that can pull in everything, even light. Scientists study them to understand how the universe began and how things like stars and galaxies form. This article talks about new discoveries from space photos that help solve a puzzle about red dots.
Article_Structure: WHO: Scientists from the University of Copenhagen
WHAT: Found that red dots in space photos are young black holes hidden in gas clouds
WHERE: In the distant universe, seen by the James Webb Space Telescope
WHY: To learn how black holes grow and understand the early universe

perspectives.description: Scientists used data to solve a mystery and share new knowledge about space
